results.name: Remove all trailing bits equal to (n mod 2) in binary representation of n.
comment: The original name was: "The changepoint a(n) is the first predecessor from n in a binary tree with: a(n) mod 2 <> n mod 2."
any node has 2 successors and one predecessor. a(n) is the first predecessor from n (going back, step by step) with another last digit (in binary sight) as n.
The subsequences from a(2^k) to a(2^(k+1) - 1) are permutations from the natural numbers from 0 to 2^k-1.
a(2^n -1) = 0 and a(2^n) = 1. a(2n-1) is 2x and a(2n) is 2x+1. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 04 2015
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..8192
example: a(7) = a(111_2) = 0_2 = 0 (when the rightmost and only run of bits in 7's binary representation has been shifted off, only zero remains).
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{idn = IntegerDigits[n, 2], m = Mod[n, 2]}, While[ idn[[-1]] == m, idn = Most@ idn]; FromDigits[ idn, 2]]; Array[f, 83] (* or *)
f[n_] := Block[{m = n}, If[ OddQ@ m, While[OddQ@m, m--; m /= 2], While[ EvenQ@ m, m /= 2]]; m]; Array[f, 83] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jul 04 2015 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = {odd = n%2; while (n%2 == odd, n \= 2); return(n);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 20 2013
(MIT/GNU Scheme) (define (A163575 n) (floor->exact (/ n (expt 2 (A136480 n))))) ;; _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 05 2013
f x = if b == parity then f x' else x  where (x', b) = divMod x 2
